Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Decision Aids for Hip and Knee Osteoarthritis

Trial_Design.evidence: A multisite 2 Ã— 2 factorial randomised trial was conducted at three sites involving 1,636 patients.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a long, detailed DA or a short, interactive DA.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of two decision aids (DAs) for patients with hip or knee osteoarthritis in making informed patient-centered decisions regarding surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of informed patient-centered decisions, measured before and after the surgeon visit.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by site, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Neither participants nor clinicians were blinded, but the statistician was.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1,220 pre-visit and 967 post-visit surveys were returned.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 1,220 pre-visit and 967 post-visit surveys were returned.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The informed decision rate was 67.2%, with no significant difference between DA groups (p = 0.97) or surgeon groups (p = 0.23). Knowledge scores were higher in the short-DA group (mean difference = 9%; p < 0.001).

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT02729831).
